name: Zolpidem
summary: Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic used for the short-term treatment of insomnia.
description: Zolpidem, marketed under the brand name Ambien (and others), is a sedative-hypnotic medication indicated for the short-term treatment of insomnia characterized by difficulties with sleep initiation or maintenance. It belongs to the imidazopyridine class and acts as a selective agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and promoting sleep. It has a rapid onset of action and a relatively short half-life, reducing next-day sedation risk. Lower doses are often used to reduce the risk of next-morning impairment, particularly in women and older adults.

contraindications: History of complex sleep behaviors (e.g., sleepwalking) after zolpidem use
Hypersensitivity to zolpidem or formulation components
monitoring_required: Next-day impairment, especially with extended-release formulations

items: Short-term treatment of insomnia with difficulties in sleep initiation and/or maintenance

sections.text: Binds selectively to the benzodiazepine site of the alpha1-containing GABA-A receptor, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and promoting sleep onset.

adult.oral: Immediate-release: 5–10 mg at bedtime (use lowest effective dose; 5 mg recommended for women and older adults). Extended-release: 6.25–12.5 mg at bedtime (6.25 mg for women and older adults). Low-dose sublingual/intermezzo: 1.75–3.5 mg for middle-of-the-night awakening (only if ≥4 hours of sleep remain).

items: Sublingual tablets: 1.75 mg, 3.5 mg, 5 mg, 10 mg

sections.text: Rapid onset within 15–30 minutes; duration of action about 6–8 hours depending on formulation.

serious: complex sleep behaviors (e.g., sleepwalking, sleep driving)

other: Risk of complex sleep behaviors; discontinue immediately if they occur
May cause next-day psychomotor impairment, especially at higher doses or with insufficient sleep
Risk of dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal with prolonged use
Caution in patients with respiratory impairment, hepatic impairment, depression, or history of substance use disorder

sections.pregnancy: Limited data; use only if potential benefit outweighs risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; consider alternative or monitor infant
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity; use lowest effective dose (5 mg IR or 6.25 mg CR)

sections.text: If used for more than a few weeks, taper gradually to reduce rebound insomnia and withdrawal symptoms.

items: Should be taken immediately before bedtime, on an empty stomach
Lower doses reduce risk of next-day impairment
Intended for short-term use; reassess if insomnia persists
